inference: Classify anomalies as in-session with presence vs out-of-session without presence
Description: Align each flow anomaly alert with usage log sessions and proximity activity; anomalies that overlap a logged session and active proximity indicate user-driven extreme usage, while anomalies outside any session with no proximity suggest leaks or unlogged system behavior.
short rationale: Exposes occupancy context and distinguishes user-driven vs unattended anomalies.

inference: Leak likelihood scoring using session gaps and absence of presence
Description: For every anomaly alert, check whether a usage session is active and whether proximity shows anyone near the fixture; alerts occurring outside sessions with no proximity receive a higher leak-likelihood score than alerts during sessions with confirmed presence.
short rationale: Absence-based leak scoring reveals empty-window events.

inference: Detection of water left running after the user leaves
Description: Identify anomaly alerts where the usage log session continues and flow is abnormally high even though proximity data shows the user has left the area, revealing fixtures left running or stuck valves after the user departs.
short rationale: Shows departure timing with unattended flow.

inference: Detection of unlogged or mis-logged abnormal sessions
Description: When anomaly alerts coincide with sustained proximity activity but no corresponding usage session is recorded, the combination suggests that abnormal water use is occurring without being properly logged as a session.
short rationale: Infers unlogged use tied to presence.

inference: Crowd-driven anomaly detection in shared facilities
Description: Anomaly alerts that overlap periods with many rapid, overlapping proximity activations and multiple short usage sessions indicate crowd-driven abnormal usage patterns in public or shared restrooms.
short rationale: Reveals co-occupancy and congestion periods.

inference: Single-user misuse versus mechanical failure discrimination
Description: If anomaly alerts align with long, continuous proximity from a single user and a single extended usage session, the event is more likely due to misuse (e.g., deliberately running water) than a mechanical failure that would typically persist without presence.
short rationale: Links anomalies to a single user’s behavior.

inference: Estimating user disruption from anomalies
Description: Calculate, for each anomaly alert, how much of its duration overlaps both an active usage session and proximity presence; a larger overlap fraction indicates greater direct disruption to users compared to anomalies that occur when no one is present.
short rationale: Measures how much anomalies affect present users.

inference: Idle-period anomaly criticality assessment
Description: Use usage logs to identify time windows with historically low or no sessions; anomaly alerts that occur in these idle windows and show no proximity activity are flagged as critical, as they are unlikely to be user-driven and more likely to represent hidden failures.
short rationale: Highlights anomalies during absence windows.

inference: Sensor coverage and alignment validation from anomaly windows
Description: Repeated anomaly alerts with abnormal usage in the logs but little or no proximity activity indicate that the proximity sensor does not adequately cover where the user stands during abnormal flow, pointing to misalignment or blind spots.
short rationale: Focuses on sensor coverage with limited personal exposure.

inference: Detection of sensor crosstalk in multi-fixture environments
Description: When anomaly alerts for one fixture coincide with usage sessions at that fixture but proximity activations mainly appear at a different nearby sensor, this suggests crosstalk where users at one fixture trigger another fixture’s proximity sensor.
short rationale: Identifies sensor crosstalk; low identifiability.

inference: Queue and congestion-related anomaly identification
Description: Combine anomaly alert times with clusters of proximity activations and overlapping usage sessions to detect anomalies that happen when many people are waiting and moving around fixtures, which may stress plumbing or encourage misuse.
short rationale: Shows crowding periods and movement around fixtures.

inference: Auto-shutoff effectiveness measurement during anomalies
Description: For anomalies that should trigger automatic shutoff, examine whether abnormal flow (implied by the alert), the usage session in the logs, and proximity activity all end soon after the alert; if sessions and presence persist, auto-shutoff may be ineffective or ignored.
short rationale: Assesses response timing during user presence.

inference: Detection of repeated approach–abort behavior around anomalies
Description: Look for patterns where proximity activations show users approaching, an anomaly alert triggers during a short usage session, and users quickly leave; repeated cycles indicate a fixture that behaves abnormally early in use, causing users to abort.
short rationale: Captures hesitant/aborted attempts linked to anomalies.

inference: Segregation of occupancy-related anomalies from infrastructure-related anomalies
Description: Compare anomaly frequency during high-occupancy periods (many sessions and strong proximity activity) versus low-occupancy periods; anomalies that persist in low-occupancy windows point more strongly to infrastructure problems than those that only occur under heavy occupancy.
short rationale: Splits anomalies by occupancy level.

inference: Normalization of anomaly rates by actual presence time
Description: Compute anomaly counts per fixture and normalize by total proximity-based presence time and total logged session time; a high ratio of anomalies per hour of presence indicates fixtures that behave abnormally relative to how often they are actually used.
short rationale: Aggregated rate metric with limited personal detail.

inference: Detection of unattended abnormal operation in off-hours
Description: Align anomaly alerts with usage logs that show no sessions and proximity data that shows no people around during off-hours; anomalies in these windows reveal unattended abnormal flows that would otherwise remain unnoticed.
short rationale: Exposes off-hours unattended anomalies and absence patterns.

inference: Detection of deliberate policy circumvention behaviors
Description: If policies specify that water should only flow when presence is detected, anomaly alerts with active usage sessions but little or no proximity activity indicate that users may be circumventing presence requirements (e.g., by overriding sensors).
short rationale: Reveals policy circumvention tied to users.

inference: Prioritization of anomalies affecting many distinct presence episodes
Description: Count how many separate proximity episodes and usage sessions overlap each anomaly alert; anomalies that repeatedly disrupt many different sessions and presence episodes should be prioritized higher than those experienced by only a single, rare user.
short rationale: Ranks anomalies by number of impacted presences.

inference: Self-resolving anomaly pattern detection without user intervention
Description: Identify anomaly alerts where abnormal patterns end without any new proximity activity or the start/end of a usage session, suggesting self-resolving pressure or valve fluctuations that clear spontaneously without user interaction.
short rationale: Self-resolving behavior with little personal data.

inference: Differentiation of abnormal cleaning cycles from leaks
Description: Anomalies overlapping clusters of short usage sessions and intermittent proximity activity in cleaning time windows are likely abnormal cleaning cycles, while anomalies with no sessions and no presence indicate genuine leaks or remote actuation issues.
short rationale: Infers cleaning vs leak based on activity patterns.

inference: Dynamic adjustment of anomaly thresholds using presence-context
Description: Use historical correlations between presence, session patterns, and anomaly alerts to tune thresholds: allow slightly higher flow-related variability during high-occupancy periods with many sessions, and tighten thresholds during expected no-presence windows.
short rationale: Threshold tuning with occupancy context; low identity risk.

inference: Security anomaly detection combining off-hours presence and alerts
Description: Anomaly alerts that occur together with unexpected proximity activity during off-hours, even if usage logs show only short or partial sessions, may indicate tampering or unauthorized use of fixtures in restricted times.
short rationale: Flags off-hours presence, high security/privacy impact.

inference: Detection of valves reopening after users leave
Description: Find anomaly events where abnormal flow and alerts cease while proximity is active and a session appears to end, but then resume after proximity and session logging stop, indicating valves that spontaneously reopen in the absence of users.
short rationale: Reveals unintended flow restarting after departure.

inference: Anomaly clustering by presence and session signature
Description: Cluster anomaly alerts according to whether they occur with no session and no presence, with sessions but no presence, or with sessions and strong presence; each cluster points to different root-cause categories such as leaks, logging faults, or misuse.
short rationale: Categorizes anomalies using occupancy context.

inference: Testing effectiveness of user-facing anomaly notifications
Description: When anomaly alerts generate user-visible messages or sounds, examine whether proximity activity increases near the fixture and whether the usage session ends shortly afterward; a weak correlation suggests that alerts are not prompting users to respond.
short rationale: Measures responsiveness to alerts with timing.

inference: Early identification of fixtures prone to user-present anomalies
Description: Analyze how often anomaly alerts at a fixture coincide with active presence and ongoing sessions; fixtures with disproportionately high rates of user-present anomalies may have ergonomics or control issues that cause abnormal behavior during normal use.
short rationale: Profiles fixtures with user-present anomaly patterns.

inference: Predictive modeling of high-risk sessions based on early presence and usage signals
Description: Use early patterns in proximity activations and the initial phase of the usage session (e.g., rapid re-triggers, unusual session start times) to predict which sessions are likely to generate anomaly alerts later, enabling proactive monitoring or warnings.
short rationale: Predicts risky sessions from early behavioral cues.

inference: Validation of occupancy models using anomaly and session data
Description: Compare building-level occupancy expectations with actual proximity and usage logs during anomaly alerts; anomalies with no presence or sessions during assumed ‘occupied’ windows indicate mismatches between occupancy models and real fixture usage.
short rationale: Exposes mismatches between expected and real occupancy.

inference: Quantifying unobserved risk from anomalies when users are absent
Description: Aggregate anomaly alerts that occur without overlapping sessions or proximity; their durations and recurrence provide a measure of how often risky abnormal flows occur without anyone nearby to notice them.
short rationale: Absence-based risk quantification for unattended events.

inference: Context-aware escalation of anomalies based on affected session type
Description: Cross-reference anomalies with the characteristics of overlapping sessions (e.g., short vs long, frequent vs rare) and presence behavior; anomalies disrupting critical or vulnerable session types (such as those inferred to involve children or elderly users) are escalated more aggressively.
short rationale: Escalation based on session type, potentially inferring vulnerable users.
